Issues.Title: Angular Universal not rendering on server and keep showing the static version
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package I have no idea. ### Is this a regression? Did not tried with older versions. ### Description I implemented server side rendering in a new angular 9 project and when I test it running **npm run build:ssr && npm run serve:ssr** everything works as expected, I check the source code that the browser received (view-source:) and is SSR. But when I deploy the project to firebase hosting **npm run build:all && firebase deploy (or even firebase serve)** and check the source code (view-source:) it is the static version, it just shows the app-root tag, despite not showing any errors on the console. I don't know if it's an error in the implementation or a problem with a package or version. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I just generated a new project, added angular universal (ng add @nguniversal/express-engine). Init firebase, update public and rewrites fields in firebase.json, add the scripts to package.json (in src and functions folder) and add the ssr function (universal) to functions/src/index.ts . ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: refactor(forms): store raw validators in addition to combined validators function
Issues.Body:
NOTE: this is an **experimental** PR to test how we can store original list of validators and check whether such change would be compatible with existing apps in Google's codebase.

This commit refactors the way we store validators in AbstractControl-based classes: in addition to the combined validators function that we have, we also store the original list of validators. This is needed to have an ability to clean then up later at destroy time (currently it's problematic since they are combined in a single function) to avoid memory leaks.


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(forms): store raw validators in addition to combined validators function" (#37881)

Issues.Title: Automatically reduce number of placeholder comment nodes for ngIf and ngSwitch
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/common/src/directives/ng_switch.ts


### Description

When using ngIf or ngSwitch the framework adds comment nodes to the DOM that act as placeholders. This can become a performance issue, for example with a large switch block (50 cases) inside a component that is repeated many times (1000+). Each inactive switch case has a placeholder comment node for each 

In some manual tests I did, the chrome memory profiler showed that there were > 13000 comment nodes, and most of them were from a single ngSwitch inside a table cell component (I tested this by removing all the cells). This accounted for over 4% of total memory consumption in a large app. According to a theory of mine this will also slow down other actions on the page due to the increased DOM size which decreases the cache locality of non-comment elements.


### Describe the solution you'd like

I have a theory that the framework can automatically skip creating comment nodes that are unnecessary. For ngSwitch, no comment nodes should be necessary if there are no "interleaved" elements or text content between the switch cases. If there is only one "interleaved" thing, then only one comment node should be necessary to keep track of the location of the inactive group of cases.

The same trick should also work for ngIf, with the caveat that we still need placeholder comment nodes unless the compiler knows that the if blocks are mutually exclusive, and also they don't have content between them.

I hope this makes sense, but please let me know if I can clarify anything. I'm sure there are other good solutions too, so I would like to start some brainstorming.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Automatically reduce number of placeholder comment nodes for ngIf and ngSwitch" (#37880)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove unused fakeAsyncFallback and asyncFallback
Issues.Body:
`zone.js` 0.8.25 introduces `zone-testing` bundle and move all `fakeAsync/async` logic
from `@angular/core/testing` to `zone.js` package. But in case some user still using the old
version of `zone.js`, an old version of `fakeAsync/async` logic were still kept inside `@angular/core/testing`
package as `fallback` logic. Since now `Angular8+` already use `zone.js 0.9+`, so
those fallback logic can be removed.

Issues.Title: DomSanitizer doesn't work for background-image URLs
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug description I have issues in Angular 10 with the sanitation of URLs on Background-images on DIV-elements. On a regular IMG tag the sanitation works. But on Background-images the URL doesn't get rendered. At the place were the path should appear in the console there is just an 'undefined'. No error gets logged. The URLs that should be rendered are System paths. The Angular app is embedded inside an Electron app. **app.component.ts** ` sanitize(imgURL) { return this.sanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustUrl(imgURL); }` And the corresponding HTML with the IMG - Tag working: `` And this is a similar HTML configuration but with background-image in a div instead of an IMG tag. `
` ### Affected Package I think the issue is with the DomSanitizer which resides in @angular/platform-browser ### Is this a regression? This feature regarding online forums did work in the past. ### Github Repository [ImageWall](https://github.com/foxfire/ImageWall)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DomSanitizer doesn't work for background-image URLs" (#37877)

Issues.Title: Failed to set the 'responseType' property on 'XMLHttpRequest'
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/http ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version might have had this bug. I can see this being discussed by people in 2018 on Stackoverflow. ### Description From the research that I did, this seems to happening if one of the JS assets on your page is making a synchronous request. Sometimes, a tracking library included on the page is making synchronous calls and is messing up with the angular HTTP requests. You can find related questions here: - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49666138/not-able-to-use-httpclient-in-angular-5/52158459#comment110802776_52158459 - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49048060/subscribing-to-httpclient-get-method-results-in-an-xmlhttprequest-error/62656061#62656061 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction For minimal reproduction, please refer to the repo here: https://github.com/haseebahmed7/angular-bugrepro-37875 ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Give Universal project more love
Issues.Body:
Hi,

prerendering and dynamic server-side rendering is essential feature in today B2C sites.

The continuing feature of Angular Universal is that there is almost no documentation.

There used to be a showcase repo [universal-starter](https://github.com/angular/universal-starter) that allowed us to see how the prerendering was done (despite not documented at the time). This repo is now archived.

We are currently stuck with Angular 8, because there is no documentation, how to upgrade the prerender / SSR logic from existing solution. This is especially painful in more complicated scenarios, such as dynamic routes generation preceding prerendering phase.

When competing with React and Vue, Universal should be showcased as first class citizen. Instead, it mostly seem like unwanted cousin.

Please, give Angular Universal more love.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Give Universal project more love" (#37871)

Issues.Title: For the benefit of new users, please emit an error for `*ngFor="let b in a"` instead of `*ngFor="let b of a"`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description
I've repeatedly experienced inconvenience with the expression format `*ngFor="for ... in ..."`. Each time, I have had to take the penalty of a full build of my whole project folder before I noticed the issue.  Please fail the build sooner; I have to imagine this impacts new users even more often.

### Describe the solution you'd like
In AOT, emit an error.  In my project, no error is emitted before runtime.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
This is a request for new users.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "For the benefit of new users, please emit an error for `*ngFor="let b in a"` instead of `*ngFor="let b of a"`" (#37869)

Issues.Title: fix(core): handle spaces after `select` and `plural` ICU keywords
Issues.Body:
Currently when the `plural` or `select` keywords in an ICU contain trailing spaces (e.g. `{count, select , ...}`), these spaces are also included into the key names in ICU vars (e.g. "VAR_SELECT "). These trailing spaces are not desirable, since they will later be converted into `_` symbols while normalizing placeholder names, thus causing mismatches at runtime (i.e. placeholder will not be replaced with the correct value). This commit updates the code to trim these spaces while generating an object with placeholders, to make sure the runtime logic can replace these placeholders with the right values.

Another approach that I was considering is to trim these spaces at the Lexer level, but that would be a big breaking change affecting a portion of apps due to the fact that i18n message ids would be changed in this case.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] No

Issues.Title: Commit body is calculated incorrectly in some cases
Issues.Body:
While investigating the problem with `docs` scope exclusion from min body length checks (see https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/37862), I noticed that the commit body that we use for length check also includes the content that would be dropped after the commit is made. For example when I make some change, run the `git commit` command and presented with the screen to type commit message like this:

```
docs: some test

# Please enter the commit message for your changes. Lines starting
# with '#' will be ignored, and an empty message aborts the commit.
#
# On branch docs-test
# Changes to be committed:
#	modified:   aio/content/marketing/resources.json
#
# Changes not staged for commit:
#	modified:   .ng-dev/config.ts
#
```

Everything below the first 2 lines (all lines that start with `#`) are treated as commit body, thus passing the min length validation even though it would later fail on CI.

The proposal is to process commit body before performing the length check and remove all lines that start with `#`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Commit body is calculated incorrectly in some cases" (#37865)

Issues.Title: fix(router): properly compare array queryParams for equality
Issues.Body:
array queryParams will be judged as different if the arrays do not contain the same frequency of elements and the same otherwise.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
The queryParams observable or queryParamMap observables were not being fired when the params were arrays that hit an edge case in the equality check.

The `equalArraysOrString` function doesn't do an index-by-index comparison. Rather it just makes sure that for each value in the first array, that value exists anywhere in the 2nd array.

So [4, 4, 2] -> [4, 3, 2] does not emit because 4 and 2 exist in the 2nd array. The other way around works as expected [4, 3, 2] -> [4, 4, 2] because 3 does not exist in the 2nd array.

Issue Number:  #37709


## What is the new behavior?
Now the equality check for arrays ensures that both arrays have the same frequency of values in any order.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

the current implemention only call `clearNative(id)`, but it should call on object `global` like
`clearNative.call(global, id)`. Otherwise in some env, it will throw error

No, Angular compile errrors have always been worthless. They ultimately create a toxic environment for the developer because hugh amounts of time are spent tracking them down, going into Angular Build internals, Searching Stack Overflow, Looking here, Looking there. Losing time when there's no time to loose. ### Description I'm sure that all of these issues were caused by something I did... but why make it so difficult to fix things with poor build error messages? I've hit every one of these in past two weeks! It's stopped progress completely until each could be worked out. This first one is what I'm stuck on now, and the final straw. Issues.Title: Choose injector when creating components
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

@angular/core

### Description

Often, I'd like to inject different values into different components. For example, have a component tree with `color: 'BLUE` injected, and another component tree with `color: 'RED'` injected.

This sort of desire comes up in a lot of different forms. Sometimes the component tree exist contemporaneously; other times they don't (e.g. router-like functionality).

The point of dependency injection is to not code against fixed values, however Angular's DI currently makes it cumbersome to adjust the injector.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Specify the injector when creating the component. Example syntax:

```ts
export class RootComponent {
  constructor(private readonly injector: Injector) {}
  readonly blueProviders: StaticProviders[] = [{ provide: COLOR, useValue: 'BLUE' }];
  readonly blueInjector = Injector.create(this.blueProviders, this.injector);
}
```

```html
<my-component [@injector]="blueInjector"></my-component>
```

or

```html
<my-component [@providers]="blueProviders"></my-component>
```


### Describe alternatives you've considered

1. Inject an `Observable`. However that complicates client code, and requires components to understand how to handle changes.

2. Use non-template code to dynamically create components. However, lifecycles methods, etc. make the approach complex in general.

3. Use `*ngComponentOutlet`. However, like (2), that removes the ability to use inputs with the child component, and it requires explicitly adding components to module entry points.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Choose injector when creating components" (#37857)

Issues.Title: Type guards in template
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Description Use [in type guards](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/advanced-types.html#using-the-in-operator), [instanceof type guards](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/advanced-types.html#instanceof-type-guards) and [typeof type guards](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/advanced-types.html#typeof-type-guards) in Angular template. --- Use case demonstrated in react jsx: ```jsx declare const data: Date | string; return
date message is {data instanceof Date ? formatDate(data) : data}
``` ```jsx declare const data: number | string; return
date message is {typeof data === 'number' ? formatNumber(data) : data}
``` Here is just the simplest example without nesting. In the scenario of nested multi-layer ngFor ngSwitch data display, if NgTemplate supports it, we can omit the function of writing data conversion, which will be very convenient. ```jsx type Data = Array<{ classRoomId: string; students: Array<{ name: string; value: Array<{ data: string | Date; }>; }>; }>; declare const data: Data; declare function formatDate(x: Date): string; const jsxWithInstanceofTypeGuard = (
{data.map(classRoom => ( <> {classRoom.classRoomId}
    {classRoom.students.map(({ name, value }) => ( <> name:{name} value: {value.map(x => x.data instanceof Date ? formatDate(x.data) : x.data, )} ))}
))}
); function transformData(data: Data) { return data.map(classRoom => ({ ...classRoom, students: classRoom.students.map(({ name, value }) => ({ name, value: value.map(v => v.data instanceof Date ? ({ type: 'Date', v, } as const) : ({ type: 'number', v, } as const), ), })), })); } const jsxWithoutInstanceofTypeGuard = (
{transformData(data).map(classRoom => ( <> {classRoom.classRoomId}
    {classRoom.students.map(({ name, value }) => ( <> name:{name} value: {value.map(x => (x.type === 'Date' ? formatDate(x.v.data) : x.v.data))} ))}
))}
); ``` The above is a small example demonstrated with react. If we want to prevent the use of *instanceof type guard* in the template, we need to add a lot of code to handle data conversion.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Type guards in template" (#37851)

Issues.Title: build: update validate-commits script to tell us valid scopes
Issues.Body:
The commit linter expects a certain scope in the commit message,
but if the right scope is not provided it doesn't tell us what to do.

Instead of this:
```
The following commit has an unknown type. You can use wip: to avoid this.
```

It now outputs this:
```
The following commit has an unknown type. It must be one of [docs, refactor, style, test, feat, fix, build, revert, ci, release]. You can use wip: to avoid this.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: update validate-commits script to tell us valid scopes" (#18106)

Issues.Title: Improve documentation for major release
Issues.Body:
This PR documents some of the learnings from the recent v10.0.0 release.
Our release doc does not sufficiently capture the process of a major release, and our tooling is insufficient to support the workflow.

There are two commits:
1. Update the release doc
    - It now reminds the caretaker to double check the versions we are about to release.
    - It adds instructions for major release.
2. Add a script to automatically retag CLI packages.

Since there isn't a test for the scripts, the best I could do is attach the command output.

```
$ yarn run -s admin dist-tag --version 10.0.0 --tag latest --verbose
npm dist-tag add @angular/cli@10.0.0 latest

Issues.Title: ng update: --allow-dirty should be the default
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [x] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

This might be a controversial opinion, but It seems odd to me that a compiler/bundler/linter would be opinionated about my version control status, or even my choice of VCS. I'd argue that angular cli should be agnostic about my git status.

If users want this behavior, I think it's fine to support it (i.e. with a `--disallow-dirty` flag), but that should be opt-in rather than opt-out.

Issues.Title: Use TSConfig bases in npm to reduce the number of TSConfigs in a project
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

:wave: - hi folks. I got notified that we could probably improve the default template for an angular project using the tsconfig bases repo. A. quick 5m explainer on [the project is here](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript-Website/issues/130#issuecomment-652399262). 

Disclaimer: I've never built an Angular app, so some of this is from looking at the base template, and I'm not sure how tsconfig's would evolve over time in large projects.

### Relevant Package

`ng generate`'s template

### Description

TSConfig files can come from NPM, and [TSConfig Bases](https://github.com/tsconfig/bases/) is a DefinitelyTyped-like tool for making them. Today, there are a few recommended bases for frameworks (svelte, react-native, deno etc) and given there are a few angular TSConfigs then I think it could be possible to move them into node_modules. 

So for example there could be 

- `@tsconfig/angular-base` 
- `@tsconfig/angular-test`  

Which the user's projects can extend from.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use TSConfig bases in npm to reduce the number of TSConfigs in a project" (#18101)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): several fixes for commonjs warnings
Issues.Body:
**fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): match allowed dependencies against the package name**

With this change we add the functionality to also match an allowed dependency against a package name. The package name is retrieved from the rawRequest.

Previously, users needed to add the request path which in some case might be a deep import. Ex: `zone.js/dist/zone-error`. With this change adding the package name example `zone.js` will suffice.

Closes: #18058

**fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): show warning when using non global locale data**

When using the `localize` option directly importing locale data from `@angular/common` is not needed because the Angular CLI  will automatically include locale data. When not using the `localize` option, most likely users meant to import the global variant of the local data.

See: https://angular.io/guide/i18n#import-global-variants-of-the-locale-data
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): several fixes for commonjs warnings " (#18081)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use copy-on-write asset processing for non-watch builds
Issues.Body:
Optimized asset processing was only being performed when differential loading was enabled.  This change ensures that the optimized approach is used for all non-watch builds.  This does not affect `ng serve` usage since it currently requires all application files to be in memory.

10.0.x variant of https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/17988
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use copy-on-write asset processing for non-watch builds" (#18086)

Issues.Title: Angular v10 - Excessive memory consumption at build
Issues.Body:
Since upgrading to Angular 10, the build process takes an excessive amount of RAM, making it impossible to deploy on Heroku (build fails with OOM error). For the same code, just upgraded: - Angular 9 memory consumption at prod build: **~2 to 2.5 Gb**. - Angular 10 memory consumption at prod build: **~8 to 9 Gb**. Heroku limit is 2.5 Gb, so it fails with Angular 10. On my local computer, with no such memory limit, the build works ok. # üêû bug report ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description The memory spike seems to occur after `ngcc` has finished its pre-compilation steps `es2015 to esm2015` and starts actual compilation of the code. **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: externalSchematic doesn't work for globally installed nested dependencies
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [x] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?

Yes, this previously worked in v8


### Description

Using "externalSchematic" on a collection defined in a dependency of a custom schematic, does not work when the custom schematic is installed globally. Globally installed npm packages are not flattened/deduped and the nested collection dependency is not found by "externalSchematic".


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
Running `ng new -c schematic-1`. 

"schematic-1" is installed globally (`npm i schematic-1 -g`) and has an npm dependency on "schematic-2". 

Under the global node_modules folder, "schematic-1" has a nested node_modules folder containing "schematic-2". If installed locally, npm will flatten the dependencies and "schematic-1" and "schematic-2" will be siblings, but a global install will nest "schematic-2" under "schematic-1".

"schematic-1" calls `externalSchematic('schematic-2', 'ng-add', options),` from `ng new`.

When installed globally, this fails with "Collection schematic-2 cannot be resolved" When installed locally, and dependencies are flatted, this succeeds.

## üî• Exception or Error
Collection schematic-2 cannot be resolved


## üåç Your Environment
Angular CLI: 9.1.9
Node: 10.21.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular:
...
Ivy Workspace:

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.901.9
@angular-devkit/core         9.1.9
@angular-devkit/schematics   9.1.9
@schematics/angular          9.1.9
@schematics/update           0.901.9
rxjs                         6.5.4

Issues.Title: Add anyComponentScript to budgets in angular.json
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

Maybe cli but I am not sure which package handles the budget feature.


### Description

Budget feature is cool but it is not possible to limit the component sizes since using bundle type vendor and anyScript together will always test vendor with anyScript and therefore setting anyScript low will always print an error for vendor.

```json
              "budgets": [
                {
                  "type": "bundle",
                  "name": "main",
                  "maximumWarning": "10kb",
                  "maximumError": "15kb"
                },
                {
                  "type": "bundle",
                  "name": "polyfills",
                  "maximumWarning": "40kb",
                  "maximumError": "70kb"
                },
                {
                  "type": "bundle",
                  "name": "styles",
                  "maximumWarning": "50kb",
                  "maximumError": "100kb"
                },
                {
                  "type": "bundle",
                  "name": "vendor",
                  "baseline": "400kb",
                  "maximumWarning": "100kb",
                  "maximumError": "150kb"
                },
                {
                  "type": "anyComponentStyle",
                  "maximumError": "6kb"
                },
                {
                  "type": "anyScript",
                  "maximumWarning": "100kb",
                  "maximumError": "150kb"
                }
              ]
```


Result:

```
chunk {} runtime.e772bc65b2af9e99c1ee.js (runtime) 2.49 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {1} 1.a5fc9c20980d9951ff60.js () 91.9 kB  [rendered]

chunk {4} 4.c6567bebe63581a306d3.js () 79.2 kB  [rendered]
chunk {5} 5.d3dad6f41426fcca8afc.js () 47.7 kB  [rendered]
chunk {6} main.5696fb0a7e865f60a76a.js (main) 5.35 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {7} polyfills.f546300ad6c2ec9ddb69.js (polyfills) 36.1 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {8} styles.57c4e806b9d984501a87.css (styles) 11.3 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {9} vendor.b38628b2815959eb1e83.js (vendor) 399 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {10} 10.afc77e53d9411a9d1a8d.js () 16.3 kB  [rendered]
chunk {11} 11.1b5b29fed06c656fbb29.js () 49.5 kB  [rendered]
chunk {12} 12.03df42d75cd1b7840830.js () 4.51 kB  [rendered]
chunk {13} 13.6372db319c894cfe1771.js () 80.9 kB  [rendered]
chunk {14} 14.5385f2b39faf73e68e6c.js () 1.14 kB  [rendered]
chunk {15} 15.93ef0e98cf22f6d95c4d.js () 2 kB  [rendered]
Date: 2020-07-01T08:49:04.006Z - Hash: f5e4fc3e03db926ce6b4 - Time: 27694ms

WARNING in budgets: Exceeded maximum budget for vendor.b38628b2815959eb1e83.js. Budget 100 kB was not met by 299 kB with a total of 399 kB.

ERROR in budgets: Exceeded maximum budget for vendor.b38628b2815959eb1e83.js. Budget 150 kB was not met by 249 kB with a total of 399 kB.
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.

A new bundle type name `anyComponentScript`.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Maybe an excluding path prop for a budget, e.g. `exclude: "{vendor,main}.*"`

Issues.Title: Standard Documentation for Angular Applications and Libraries
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request: Standard Documentation for Angular Applications

### Relevant Package
aio and tooling

### Description
Create application documentation ain't easy. Various kind of applications and components need to be documented to be extended by other developers.

A standardized approach could greatly improve tooling around this kind of solutions (think plugins).

### Describe the solution you'd like
1. I would find it incredibly useful to be able to run a command (maybe a ng-schematics extension?) that would take my application created and maintained via ng-new / ng-add and add documentation scafolding.
1. I would also like to be able to launch a commad (think aio on Angular) that create the documentation site for my application following standard Angular guidelines and feature set.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
[CompoDoc](https://compodoc.app/) - While a valid alternative It doesn't provide all the features of the standard Angular documentation site.

Issues.Title: Ng build fails always using aws codebuild
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... No ### Description We're using aws codebuild for building and the build process always fails and exits without providing any info , it says : Command did not exit successfully , the full message is : "Command did not exit successfully node --max-old-space-size=4096 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod exit status 1". ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I'm going to mention aws codebuild support team response as following : """ Hi Rami, I hope you are doing well and taking good care of your health during this pandemic. Thank you for getting back to us with the requested information. I am glad to assist you further. Before I commence, I would like to apologise for the delayed response. As I was replicating the issue in my environment, it took me a while to get back to you. I hope that you understand it and co-operate with me. Investigation made - --------------------- Initially I have thoroughly gone through the "verbose" log you have sent me on the case. However, even in the verbose logs, I was unable to observe any particular error messages. Later, I have made use of the "package.json" file to install the same dependencies which you are using to test the build. I installed the dependencies and used them in the CodeBuild environment to build a sample application. To replicate the issue exactly, I have made use of the same compute type and compute environment in the codebuild project that you are making use of. The environment information where I have tested the sample application is given below. However, the issue was not reproduce-able in my environment. ----------------------------------------------------------- type LINUX_CONTAINER image aws/codebuild/standard:3.0 computeType BUILD_GENERAL1_MEDIUM privilegedMode false certificate blank registryCredential blank imagePullCredentialsType CODEBUILD ----------------------------------------------------------- Later, As my area of expertise is AWS CodeBuild, to gain more understanding about the Angular CLI and "ng build" I have gone through the Angular documentations. After that, to check if there are any existing issues in the angular CLI, I checked all the existing Git issues of the Angular CLI. I found the actual issue on git where, the "ng build" just fails without any particular reason. Below is the link to the issue description. Errors in child compilers not reported, process exits without info #17565 - https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/17565 The issue affects "ng build" and "ng serve" commands. Accordingly, If a compilation includes child compilations as is the case when using worker-loader for example (or many other webpack loaders/plugins) the build process can fail and exit without providing any info but the exit code being 1. The replication steps for this error with the replication repository is given in the issue description itself. I have tried this both in my local environment and in CodeBuild as well. When I tried in the Local machine the build looks like completed as the error is not visible in the console. The local build output which I ran is given below: ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 8c859032105a:angular-child-compiler-error user$ node --max-old-space-size=4096 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod Browserslist: caniuse-lite is outdated. Please run next command `npm update` Date: 2020-06-27T07:11:23.605Z Hash: c773dc7753f32d162a5b Time: 13047ms chunk {0} runtime-es5.967b40d860653894bbb2.js (runtime) 1.45 kB [entry] [rendered] chunk {1} main-es5.6a83abc16d1e39382351.js (main) 188 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {2} polyfills-es5.4e06eb653a3c8a2d581f.js (polyfills) 111 kB [initial] [rendered] 8c859032105a:angular-child-compiler-error user$ echo $? 1 8c859032105a:angular-child-compiler-error user$ ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ You can see that the build looks completed in the local machine. However, the exit code of the command is 1. This can be the reason that the Build looks like working fine when it ran Locally in your case as well. To replicate the issue in CodeBuild environment, I have made use of the below buildspec file and the replication was successful. You can use this buildspec for the further replication on you end. ------------------------------------------------ version: 0.2 phases: build: commands: - git init - git clone https://github.com/nadavsinai/angular-child-compiler-error.git - cd angular-child-compiler-error - npm install - node --max-old-space-size=4096 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod --verbose ------------------------------------------------- I have also tried with the angularcli vesrion 8.0.6 and 8.0.3 which is running in your environment. This version also has the same issue and the error is reproduce-able. ======================================================================================== Having said that, the issue seems more specific to the anularcli and application you are building rather than the CodeBuild environment. As I have just started with the Angular and My area of expertise is AWS CodeBuild, I may not able to debug the reason for the error. However, we can be sure that AWS CodeBuild is not having any direct relation with the issue we are observing. Rather, the issue is specific to angular and how it handles the compilation which includes child compilations. I hope that you understand this. """" ## üî• Exception or Error 

Command did not exit successfully node --max-old-space-size=4096 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod exit status 1
## üåç Your Environment 


Angular CLI: 8.0.3
Node: 12.16.1
OS: linux x64
Angular: 8.0.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/platform): rtl scroll axis incorrectly determined in Safari macOS
Issues.Body:
In Safari on macOS, the RTL scroll axis is determined incorrectly when
scrollbars are set to `Always Display` as per macOS general system
preferences. Our test element for the scroll axis sets a fixed height.

This is resulting in a vertical scroll bar as the horizontal scroll bar
for testing `scrollLeft` exceeds the scroll containers `1px` height. The
vertical scroll bar then unveils a bug in Webkit where space is acquired
on the right side for the scroll bar (while it's displayed on the left).

This space causes our scroll axis detection to break as the horizontal
`scrollLeft` unexpectedly expands to: `[-scrollWidth, 15px]` while
usually `0px` is the right boundary. We fix this by simply ensuring
that no vertical scroll bar is ever displayed. The vertical scrolling
is not needed for determining the RTL horizontal scroll axis type.

I've reported a bug upstream in Webkit:
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=213851.

I tested manually on Chrome 83.0.4103.116 Windows 10; macOS High Sierra Firefox 77; macOS High Sierra Safari 11.1, macOS Mojave Safari 12.1, macOS Catalina Safari 13.1, Windows 10 IE11.900.18362.0. Unfortunately there are no tests for this feature detection, nor would it be easy to write one for the particular scenario where a macOS setting is required.

Fixes #14609.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/platform): rtl scroll axis incorrectly determined in Safari macOS" (#19830)

Issues.Title: build: add custom linting for symbol names
Issues.Body: As discussed, we want to prefix some exported class names with an underscore so it's more obvious that they're private. The problem is that our current class naming rule doesn't allow for a class to start with an underscore. These changes add a custom rule that can use a regex to validate the class name. Having our own rule allows us to validate more types of nodes as well (e.g. `type` nodes which tslint doesn't check).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: add custom linting for symbol names" (#19811)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(COMPONENT): Textual improvements of the progress-bar documentation
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

In the documentation on progress bars, a few times the description says "... where the user wants to indicate ..." but this is incorrect. The user does not want to indicate anything here. Also, the texts are gramatically incorrect and confusing.

https://material.angular.io/components/progress-bar/overview#buffer

- Current text: "Operations where the user wants to indicate some activity or loading from the server, use the buffer indicator."
- Suggestion: "Use the buffer indicator to indicate loading from the server in addition to the actual progress."

https://material.angular.io/components/progress-bar/overview#query

- Current text: "For situations where the user wants to indicate pre-loading (until the loading can actually be made), use the query indicator."
- Suggestion: "Use the query indicator to indicate pre-loading before the actual loading starts."

Thanks,
Peter
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(COMPONENT): Textual improvements of the progress-bar documentation" (#19817)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-sidenav): Expansion-panel inside sidenav wont expand
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-sidebar-bug

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-sidebar-bug
2. Open https://angular-sidebar-bug.stackblitz.io/sidebaritem/sidebarsubitem in the preview browser on stackblitz
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

In the example, app-sidebar is used inside mat-sidenav and inside mat-sidenav-content. 
The app-sidebar inside mat-sidenav should behave the same way as if inside mat-sidenav-content - when URL https://angular-sidebar-bug.stackblitz.io/sidebaritem/sidebarsubitem is opened, app-sidebar should be expanded.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The app-sidebar component inside mat-sidenav does not expand - even after clicking the arrow on SidebarItem
The app-sidebar component inside mat-sidenav-content expands nicely. 

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.11
- CDK/Material: 9.2.4
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

#### Additional notes: 

The original issue we noticed is slightly different: when loading the page while the tab is active, the sidebar will expand nicely. If the page is loading in the background (user is looking at another tab while waiting to load), it won't expand. 
Additionally, this issue was reproduced on Chromium browsers (Chrome, new Edge, Opera, etc). Firefox works nicely. 
In the example above, Firefox will expand the sidebar after toggling it a few times.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-sidenav): Expansion-panel inside sidenav wont expand" (#19808)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(MapMarker): ExportAs in documentation is missing
Issues.Body:
#### mapMarker component is not using the instance of the component in local variable template


After google maps components has gotten exportAs, you can't acces the instance of mapMarker, the way described in the documentation.

The local variable should be like this: `#marker="mapMarker"`

Suggestion to updated documentation:
`
  <map-marker #marker="mapMarker"
              *ngFor="let markerPosition of markerPositions"
              [position]="markerPosition"
              [options]="markerOptions"
              (mapClick)="openInfoWindow(marker)"></map-marker>
`

Issues.Title: bug(mat-date-range-picker): MatEndDate dateChanged is triggered by changes to start and end date
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Stackblitz demo: 

https://components-issue-aypuzh.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a MatDateRangePicker as shown in the docs
2. Add the dateChanged attribute to matStartDate or matEndDate
3. Start to change dates  
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

That the date changed attribute on matEndDate is only triggered when you change the end date. Or a way to detect when both start and end date have successfully been set.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The date changed attribute on matEndDate is triggered both when you change the start and end date.
#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.0
- CDK/Material: Material 10.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-date-range-picker): MatEndDate dateChanged is triggered by changes to start and end date" (#19806)
